Issues.Body:

## What is the current behavior?
`FormArray` `.push()` currently only accepts a single `FormControl` or `FormGroup`, manipulating a `FormArray` holding large datasets and using expensive validators is complicated by this behavior, as there is no easy way to refresh the dataset without breaking existing streams depending on its `.valueChanges`.

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?
`FormArray` `.push()` now accepts both a single `FormControl` or `FormGroup`, but also accepts an array of the same types. In case of an array, it will register all controls as expected and emit a single event after.


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [X] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information
Ran into this issue myself working at a client, where we could not easily manipulate a `FormArray` where we want to refresh a large dataset. Swapping it out for a `new FormArray()` seemed like the way, but this broke any existing streams subscribed to its original `.valueChanges`, making it difficult to keep everything in sync and reactive. 

This solution at least makes it possible to manipulate a dataset within a `FormArray` as a new dataset, instead of having to iterate over all new controls. A possible expansion on this solution, and to promote immutability, could be to offer an additional method that also internally clears the existing dataset so a full replace would be possible.

Additionally, managed to run the entire test suite locally, except for `//packages/zone.js/test:karma_jasmine_test_ci_chromium` which seemed to not be able to connect to its ChromeHeadless browser and therefore fail. Issues.Title: Form groups initialized in FormBuilder can't be initially disabled
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

forms

### Description

Currently to disable a formgroup. You first initialize it and then call group.disable()

```
this.group= this.fb.group({
  "firstName": [''],
  "middleName": [{value: '', disabled: true}, Validators.required],
  "lastName": ['']
});
this.group.disable(); // not ideal
```

You've made a beautiful, nearly feature complete declarative API.
I mean, Ideally the input to formbuilder would be fully serializable with an intermediary layer for insantiating validators, but that's not in scope for this issue.

****

### Proposed solution

Add disabled? boolean to new interface FormGroupOptions extends AbstractControlOptions

```
this.group = this.fb.group({
  "firstName": [''],
  "middleName": [{value: '', disabled: true}, Validators.required],
  "lastName": ['']
}, {disabled: true}); // nice! the API is fully declarative
```

### Alternatives considered

It can be done progamatically, as can everything the formbuilder does.
You could also return the formgroup on methods like disable() so that it's a chainable operation
```
this.fb.group({}).addValidators([]).disable();
```

Issues.Title: Extended diagnostics do not run on structural directive attributes
Issues.Body:
This came up while I was working on #57033. The visitor that is meant to visit every expression in a template currently skips over the `templateAttrs` ([see](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/4ac39aeea988bd423795bac70d480620f49f2267/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/extended/api/api.ts#L189)). This is incorrect, because the `templateAttrs` don't get copied over into the element node for something like `
`. As a result, our current extended diagnostics haven't been checking the expressions of structural directives. In #57033 I tried fixing it, but there were a lot of failures even for the trial run so I expect a lot more for a global one. As a workaround in #57033, I've added a flag that allows the problematic diagnostics to retain their old behavior, but eventually we should remove the `canVisitStructuralAttributes` flag and resolve the failures.

Issues.Title: Allow caching HTTP requests when URLs differ between server and client
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common, platform-browser, platform-server

### Description

As a result of #53702 and #50117, a new token `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` was added to allow mapping internal origins to external origins. However, this does not go far enough and fails to account for situations where entire paths are different between server and client. This can happen (such as in my case) when the server is in a Docker network and has direct access to other services and the browser uses a reverse proxy that allows access to the same service through path rewrites based on some known prefixes.

For example, `/api/foo` may be routed to an internal service and rewritten as `http://my-service:3000/foo`. Thus, the server needs to call `http://my-service:3000/foo` and the browser needs to call `/api/foo`. The difference between them is more than just the origin.

This same issue was mentioned in multiple comments (see below), but the final solutions that introduces `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` is somehow more limiting than the needs that were articulated. See the following comments and several others:

[#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1792077410)
[#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1832556707)

Scouring the above-mentioned issues and others, I could not find a way to address this use case, which means the transfer cache will never work for my setup.

### Proposed solution

There are several possible ways to solve this:

1. A new token similar to `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` that would allow mapping path prefixes rather than just origins.
2. A way to override the cache key as suggested in #53702, [#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1792077410), [#53702 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/53702#issuecomment-1898089674) and several others.
3. A way to compose the current root interceptor with additional functionality, though this is quite heavy-handed and may lead to unintended consequences.

### Alternatives considered

Current alternative is to use `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` and change the network setup to accommodate the limitation of only being able to map origins and not paths. However, this is quite disruptive, and I would rather not make a change this big to accommodate the limitations of the frontend framework.

I had also attempted to use my own interceptor to rewrite URLs, similar to [#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1602675046), but this won't work as explained in the same comment.

One last option is to not rely on the transfer cache at all through `withNoHttpTransferCache()`, but this is effectively what's happening in my case without doing anything anyway.

### Description

This is more or less a continuation of #27949. I was testing the fix for that issue in Angular 18.1.0 and found that it is still not working. And since I cannot reopen that issue I'm writing this new one.

Whenever I try to access a static file without a trailing slash, angular returns a redirect to the same path with a trailing backslash.

Get: /oauth2redirect

location: /oauth2redirect/

**But if the path contains a query string, then the trailing backslash is added to the end of the query string**:
